questions.text: A previously healthy 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother after she noticed multiple skin lesions on her abdomen. The child attends daycare three times per week, and this past week one child was reported to have similar lesions. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her brother had chickenpox 1 month ago. She is at the 50th percentile for height and the 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the lesions is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Insect bites (e.g., mosquito or flea) typically cause pruritic lesions and physical examination most often reveals erythematous papules at the site of the bite.

B) CORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum typically affects children < 5 years of age. The lesions are nontender, skin-colored, pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication. They are usually 2–5 mm in diameter and commonly occur on the trunk, face, and genitalia. Because spontaneous remission often occurs within a year, treatment is usually not required.

Molluscum contagiosum also occurs in adults, particularly in those with immunosuppression (e.g., HIV, chemotherapy, extensive corticosteroid therapy).

C) INCORRECT:

Folliculitis is characterized by erythema, tender papules, and/or pustules at the site of hair follicles. However, the patient's papules are nontender and there is no association with hair follicles, making the diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

A solitary pustule with surrounding erythema is visible in the center of the image. In many cases of folliculitis, a single hair can be seen in the middle of the lesion.

D) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous lichen planus most commonly manifests on the wrists and lower extremities in individuals between 30 and 60 years of age. The typical skin lesions are pruritic, polygonal, planar (flat-topped), purple plaques or papules. A pattern of white lines on the lesion's surface (Wickham striae) may also be seen. In contrast, the lesions described in the vignette are skin-colored and do not have irregular borders or Wickham striae, making the diagnosis of cutaneous lichen planus unlikely, especially in a 2-year-old girl.
Image Description:

Ventral wrist of an adult presenting with a bilateral pruritic rash

Multiple purple-red, well-demarcated, partially confluent polygonal papules can be seen. White reticular lines (Wickham striae) are also visible on the surface of the papules.

The location and appearance of this rash are typical of lichen planus.

E) INCORRECT:

Keratoacanthomas grow rapidly (within 2–3 months) in areas of skin exposed to the sun and manifest as round erythematous nodules with a central crater.
Image Description:

An erythematous nodule with a central indentation that developed in the course of 7 weeks.

These findings are consistent with keratoacanthoma, which typically manifests with a central hyperkeratotic plug, leaving an indentation after removal (as seen here).

F) INCORRECT:

Common warts (verruca vulgaris) manifest as rough, scaly papules or plaques that may sometimes have a cauliflower-like appearance and are typically located on the hands, feet, and knees.
Image Description:

Partially confluent, hyperkeratotic papules with a rough surface are seen on the dorsal surface of the hand at the level of the metacarpophalangeal joint

G) INCORRECT:

Chickenpox (varicella) typically manifests during childhood with a rash that is characterized by the simultaneous manifestation of macules, papules, vesicles, and crusts. The rash starts on the trunk, spreading to the face, scalp, and extremities and causing severe pruritus and fever.
Image Description:

Upper body of a young boy with exanthem showing the simultaneous occurrence of various stages of rash; mainly vesicles and pustules, no crusted erosions. This clinical finding is also referred to as "starry sky" and is typical of chickenpox.
questions.hint: This patient's skin lesions are typically caused by poxviruses.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with HIV infection comes to the physician because of skin lesions over his face and neck for 2 weeks. They are not itchy or painful. He does not have a fever or a sore throat. He was treated for candidal esophagitis 3 months ago. He is sexually active with his wife, who knows of his condition, and they use condoms consistently. He is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy with lamivudine, abacavir, and efavirenz. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 58 kg (128 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. Examination shows multiple skin-colored papules over his face and neck with a dimpled center. Cervical lymphadenopathy is present. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 4900/mm3, and platelet count is 143,000/mm3; serum studies and urinalysis show no abnormalities. CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 312/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In HIV-positive patients, herpesviruses are notorious for causing oral hairy leukoplakia (Epstein Barr virus), shingles (varicella-zoster virus), and Kaposi sarcoma (Human herpesvirus 8). Oral hairy leukoplakia manifests with white patches on the tongue, shingles with a painful maculopapular rash that quickly develops into vesicular lesions, and Kaposi sarcoma with purple papules. This patient has none of these findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Bartonella henselae can cause bacillary angiomatosis, which is characterized by vascular proliferation leading to solitary or multiple red, flesh-colored or colorless papules that bleed easily. Although the condition typically affects HIV-positive patients and this patient does have multiple, flesh-colored skin lesions, his lesions are dimpled and are not bleeding.
Image Description:

Two angioma-like lesions with a surrounding erythematous halo are visible.

This immunocompromised patient was diagnosed with bacillary angiomatosis due to Bartonella quintana.

C) INCORRECT:

Human papillomaviruses cause common warts, which take the form of papules with a cauliflower-like surface. Molluscum contagiosum is not caused by papillomaviruses.
Image Description:

Multiple whitish plaques and papules are visible on the distal end of the fingers. A larger hyperkeratotic plaque with a verrucous and scaly surface can be seen on the distal end of the right thumb.

Common warts are typically associated with HPV infection.

D) CORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum virus is part of the poxvirus family, which consists of large DNA viruses. Molluscum contagiosum is a condition that typically affects children, but adult patients with immunosuppression (e.g., due to HIV infection, chemotherapy, or extensive corticosteroid therapy) are also at risk of infection. Cryotherapy is the first-line treatment for adults. In this patient, the regimen and dosage of antiretroviral therapy should also be optimized because of his low CD4 count (< 350 cells/mm3).
Image Description:

Photograph of the eyelid of an adult

Multiple skin-colored papules with central umbilication are visible.

These features are characteristic of molluscum contagiosum.

E) INCORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis causes coccidioidomycosis (valley fever), which often has nonspecific findings such as fever, cough, and fatigue but can also cause erythema nodosum. Erythema nodosum is characterized by erythematous, tender nodules, which classically appear on both shins.
Image Description:

Poorly demarcated red nodules are seen on the extensor sides of both lower legs with peripheral edema of the lower left leg and foot.

These findings are characteristic of erythema nodosum.
questions.hint: This patient's skin-colored pearly and painless growths with a dimpled center indicate molluscum contagiosum.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of a rash that her mother noticed 5 months ago. The rash is not painful or itchy but she notices that her daughter sometimes picks at the “spots.” The girl's 2-year-old brother has also started developing similar skin lesions over the past month. The patient has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is in the 75th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. A photograph of the patient's rash is shown. Which of the following infectious agents is the most likely cause of this patient's skin condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Human herpesvirus 8 causes Kaposi sarcoma, which manifests with nontender, nonpruritic skin lesions, which are seen here. However, the lesions are typically a mixture of dark red macules, papules, and plaques, rather than the skin-colored and dome-shaped papules seen in this patient, and the lesions most commonly appear on the face, oral cavity, and chest. Moreover, Kaposi sarcoma occurs almost exclusively in immunocompromised patients (e.g., AIDS) and is rare in children.
Image Description:

A mixture of dark red macules, papules, and plaques are distributed asymmetrically on the skin.

These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma (caused by human herpesvirus 8).

B) INCORRECT:

The human papillomavirus types 1, 2, and 4 can cause nontender, nonpruritic, skin-colored papules in children, which are seen here. However, these lesions are common warts that typically have a cauliflower-like rather than a dome-shaped appearance, and they are usually located on the elbows, knees, fingers, or palms, rather than on the thighs. Moreover, common warts are unusual in children under 5 years of age.
Image Description:

Partially confluent, hyperkeratotic papules with a rough surface are seen on the dorsal surface of the hand at the level of the metacarpophalangeal joint

C) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus 1 can cause eczema herpeticum, which also manifests with umbilicated skin lesions. However, the lesions are typically disseminated vesicles, rather than the localized papules seen here, and are painful. Moreover, eczema herpeticum is typically accompanied by fever, malaise, and lymphadenopathy. Finally, this condition primarily occurs in patients with pre-existing skin conditions (classically atopic dermatitis), which are not reported here.
Image Description:

Multiple monomorphic, umbilicated, vesicular papules and punched-out erosions with hemorrhagic crusts are visible on the back of a young patient with a history of atopic eczema.

These findings are consistent with eczema herpeticum, a dermatological emergency requiring urgent evaluation and immediate antiviral therapy. Lesions located near the eyes require referral to ophthalmology due to the risk for corneal involvement.

D) CORRECT:

The molluscum contagiosum virus is a DNA poxvirus that typically causes multiple nontender, skin-colored, pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication, which can be located on the face, trunk, and extremities. Molluscum contagiosum most commonly affects children under 5 years of age. The virus is transmitted through direct skin contact, which explains why the patient's younger brother is also infected. Typically, the lesions are self-limiting within one year.
Image Description:

Photograph of the abdomen and groin of a young child

Single and grouped skin-colored papules with central umbilication can be seen.

These features are consistent with the diagnosis of molluscum contagiosum.

E) INCORRECT:

The varicella-zoster virus causes chickenpox, which manifests with papular skin lesions. However, the chickenpox rash is characterized by the simultaneous occurrence of various stages of rash, including crusted and erupted vesicles, which are not seen in this patient. Moreover, the skin lesions are typically highly pruritic and involve all body parts, including the mucous membranes. Finally, chickenpox is accompanied by constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise) and usually lasts for about a week, whereas this patient has already had skin lesions for several months.
Image Description:

Upper body of a young boy with exanthem showing the simultaneous occurrence of various stages of rash; mainly vesicles and pustules, no crusted erosions. This clinical finding is also referred to as "starry sky" and is typical of chickenpox.
questions.hint: Histological evaluation of the skin lesions would show keratinocytes with eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, also known as molluscum bodies.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of multiple skin lesions. The lesions are not painful or itchy. She has no history of serious illness. Examination of the skin shows nontender, pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication. The lesions have a diameter between 9–17 mm and are located on the face, neck, trunk, axillae, antecubital fossae, lower abdomen, and proximal thighs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassure the patient that the lesions will resolve and recommend follow-up
Perform a urine pregnancy test and recommend systemic retinoid therapy
Perform an HIV screening test and recommend cryotherapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum is typically a self-limited disease. However, this patient has widespread involvement, which is consistent with disseminated molluscum contagiosum and unlikely to resolve on its own. She, therefore, requires further management.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic retinoid therapy with isotretinoin is indicated to treat severe acne vulgaris but is not used to treat molluscum contagiosum. Severe acne vulgaris typically manifests with tender, inflammatory papules, pustules, and cysts on the face and trunk, which this patient does not have. A urine pregnancy test is indicated prior to initiating isotretinoin therapy because of the drug's teratogenic effects.
Image Description:

Cysts, nodules, papules and comedones (including multiple healed lesions with visible scarring) are visible on this patient's upper back.

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic itraconazole therapy can be used to treat invasive fungal infections (e.g., blastomycosis, histoplasmosis, aspergillosis) but is not used to treat molluscum contagiosum, which is caused by a poxvirus. Disseminated fungal infections can manifest with a widespread papular eruption, but they typically have more variable findings (e.g., nodules, ulcers, pustules). In addition, disseminated fungal infections commonly also cause extracutaneous symptoms, such as fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and weight loss, which this patient does not have.

D) INCORRECT:

Curettage is commonly used to treat localized molluscum contagiosum. Curettage of select lesions (e.g., the most bothersome lesions) may be a reasonable initial approach for this patient with disseminated molluscum contagiosum, but it may also result in multiple, large wounds that increase the risk of developing other infections. In addition, treatment alone without evaluation of possible immune system dysfunction is inappropriate in patients with extensive lesions.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical salicylic acid is a desquamating agent used as second-line therapy for localized molluscum contagiosum; it is not an appropriate therapy for this patient with disseminated molluscum contagiosum. Salicylic acid is also commonly used to treat acne vulgaris and verruca vulgaris. Acne vulgaris typically manifests with tender, inflammatory papules and pustules on the face. Verruca vulgaris typically manifests with cauliflower-like papules and/or plaques on acral surfaces.

F) CORRECT:

Because disseminated molluscum contagiosum in an adult raises concern for underlying immunocompromise, an HIV screening test is indicated for patients presenting with this condition. In the case of HIV infection, antiretroviral therapy should be initiated in conjunction with the treatment of skin lesions. Treatment for molluscum contagiosum includes cryotherapy, curettage, and topical cantharidin. Cidofovir may be considered in immunocompromised individuals with severe or refractory lesions. A reasonable initial approach for this patient is to treat the largest and/or most bothersome lesions with cryotherapy, which is a destructive method that can also stimulate an enhanced immune response to viral antigens.
Image Description:

Photograph of the eyelid of an adult

Multiple skin-colored papules with central umbilication are visible.

These features are characteristic of molluscum contagiosum.
questions.hint: This patient's widespread eruption of nontender, pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication is consistent with a diagnosis of disseminated molluscum contagiosum.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man reports a one-year history of bumps on his face. They first appeared as small, skin-colored bumps, but some have grown larger over time. Skin examination reveals multiple shiny, white to pink-colored, umbilicated papules measuring 2 mm to 4 mm (figure).
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum is a cutaneous viral infection that most often appears as small, skin-colored, pink, or white bumps with central umbilication. It is a common infection in childhood, where it does not imply immunosuppression. It is transmitted via skin-to-skin contact, such as through contact sports, or via indirect contact, such as through sharing of bath water or towels. Further lesions can occur in both children and adults due to autoinoculation.

In adults, molluscum contagiosum can occur in the genital area as a result of sexual contact; however, molluscum contagiosum can imply immunosuppression in an adult. The lesions in immunocompromised patients may look identical to those in immunocompetent individuals, or they may appear in an atypical fashion (e.g., either giant or verrucous and more widespread, most often on the face and neck).

Molluscum contagiosum is considered a clinical sign of marked HIV progression. The number of lesions generally varies inversely with the CD4 cell count, with an increased incidence when the CD4 count drops below 200 cells/mm3 . Adults with widespread molluscum contagiosum should therefore be tested for HIV infection.

Key learning point: An adult with molluscum contagiosum should be tested for HIV infection.

B) INCORRECT:

A treponemal antibody test for syphilis is not indicated, as syphilis is not associated with molluscum contagiosum. Although there are numerous potential cutaneous findings of syphilis, typical skin manifestations of secondary syphilis include red to red-brown macular or papular lesions that involve the trunk and extremities, including the palms and soles.

C) INCORRECT:

A serum angiotensin-converting-enzyme level can be elevated in granulomatous conditions, such as sarcoid; however, this patient has umbilicated, shiny papules most suggestive of molluscum contagiosum.

D) INCORRECT:

Although disseminated deep fungal infections (e.g., cryptococcosis, penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis) can mimic molluscum contagiosum, a beta-D-glucan test for fungal infection would not be indicated in an ambulatory patient who has had the above clinical findings for a year without other manifestations of a systemic fungal infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Checking red-cell transketolase activity, which would be low in a patient with thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, is inappropriate, as patients with thiamine deficiency do not develop umbilicated papules.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl is brought in for a new rash that appeared on her abdomen about 6 weeks ago and has since spread to her thigh. She is otherwise healthy.
Physical examination reveals the presence of several 3- to 5-mm, flesh-colored, dome-shaped papules, many of which have central umbilication (figure).
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this child?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum is a localized infection that is caused by a poxvirus and characterized by small (2 to 5 mm), flesh-colored papules on the face, trunk, and extremities. The papules tend to have a central depression (umbilication) and a pulpy core that can be extracted from the center. The core contains the viral particles, known as Henderson-Patterson bodies, which when visualized under light microscopy are diagnostic of the condition.

Molluscum lesions usually appear singly or in crops, are spread via autoinoculation from trauma or scratching, and can last from a few weeks to several months and even years. They tend to disappear spontaneously and may leave small, depressed scars. Treatment is not medically necessary in most cases, and the benefits and risks (pain) of treating small children should be weighed against the natural history of the disease.

There are few controlled studies of treatment efficacy for molluscum contagiosum. If the patient is not scratching the lesions, is not bothered by them cosmetically, and is otherwise healthy, treatment is often not necessary. If treatment is preferred, curettage (scraping off the lesions) or cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen can be successful in removing lesions and is commonly performed in the primary care setting. However, patients often must return multiple times to completely eradicate the lesions, and the procedures may be painful and could lead to scarring. Young children (such as this one) may be unable to tolerate the pain associated with these procedures, and aggressive treatment should therefore be avoided in this age group. If lesions are extensive, rapidly spreading, or very symptomatic — or the patient has an underlying immunodeficiency or other chronic disease — the patient may require referral to a pediatric dermatologist for management. Dermatologists often eradicate the lesions using cantharidin, which is a liquid extract from the blister beetle that causes the lesions to crust and resolve. This treatment option is painless and preferable over cryotherapy, but watchful waiting is still the preferred option in young children.

Key learning point: Flesh-colored papules with central umbilication that appear on the face, trunk, and extremities are most consistent with a diagnosis of molluscum contagiosum.

B) INCORRECT:

Salicylic acid is often used to treat common warts caused by various strains of the human papillomavirus. It is not usually used to treat molluscum. Common warts appear as raised rough (“verrucous”) papules, often with central black dots; they most commonly grow on the hands but can appear anywhere on the body.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids, such as 1% hydrocortisone ointment, are commonly used to treat eczema but are rarely used in the management of molluscum. Occasionally, molluscum will generate a “molluscum dermatitis” that develops in the surrounding areas of the molluscum and is very itchy, prompting patients to scratch; in these instances, hydrocortisone preparations may be used to prevent the patient from scratching and spreading the molluscum.

D) INCORRECT:

Griseofulvin is an antifungal drug that has no role in the eradication of molluscum contagiosum. Fungal infections on the body commonly appear as enlarged erythematous rings with central clearing.

E) INCORRECT:

Cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen can be successful in removing lesions and is commonly performed in the primary care setting. However, patients often must return multiple times to completely eradicate the lesions, and the procedure may be painful and could lead to scarring. Young children (such as this one) may be unable to tolerate the pain associated with this procedure, and aggressive treatment should therefore be avoided in this age group.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old male college student presents with a 2-week history of rash on his upper left trunk (figure). He is scheduled to compete in a wrestling tournament this weekend and is hoping to obtain clearance to participate. He reports that the rash is sometimes pruritic, but he has not had any drainage or crusting, fever or other systemic symptoms, or lesions elsewhere. The remainder of his examination is normal.
Given this patient’s presentation, when can he return to collegiate wrestling?

choices.text: Now, if the lesions are completely covered
After he has used topical terbinafine for 72 hours and all lesions have crusted over
After he has taken oral valacyclovir for 72 hours and all lesions have crusted over
After he has used topical mupirocin for 72 hours and no new lesions have appeared
After complete resolution of the lesions

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The spread of infectious skin dermatoses is a concern for clinicians, sports coaches, and trainers alike, and mitigation measures to prevent outbreaks are important, especially for contact sports.

This patient’s presentation is most consistent with molluscum contagiosum, a viral infection of the upper layers of the skin. Molluscum contagiosum is characterized by firm, flesh-colored, rounded papules measuring 2 mm to 5 mm with a shiny, umbilicated surface. The infection is spread by direct contact with the lesions and is quite contagious, making it relatively common among young athletes. In the absence of significant comorbidities or other systemic findings, the lesions are often self-limited and resolve within several months of appearance.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) has set forth specific return-to-competition guidelines for collegiate athletes with molluscum contagiosum. According to these guidelines, solitary or localized clustered lesions on the trunk or upper thigh must be completely covered for the athlete to compete. This athlete’s lesions are on his torso, are few in number, and can be covered with a gas permeable membrane and tape, in addition to clothing, before engagement in contact sports so that transmission is minimized. For more extensive infections, the lesions should be treated with curettage and then covered before return to play.

Key learning point: College wrestlers with molluscum contagiosum lesions can participate in contact sports if the lesions can be fully covered.

B) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis would typically manifest as a round or annular erythematous patch that is sometimes scaly and may be pruritic. Immunocompetent athletes with tinea corporis can typically return to play after 72 hours of treatment with a topical antifungal (such as terbinafine).

C) INCORRECT:

Herpes gladiatorum (herpes simplex virus among wrestlers) accounts for about 40% of infectious rashes in wrestlers. Lesions start as vesicles that ulcerate and then crust over several days, sometimes occurring in crops over time. Affected athletes should be treated with an antiviral medication such as valacyclovir and should not return to play until they have been on antiviral therapy for at least 5 days and all lesions have crusted over. Suppressive medication may be considered in those with a prior history.

D) INCORRECT:

Impetigo due to Staphylococcus or Streptococcus speciesis also common among athletes. Although these lesions may start as papules, they progress to vesicles or pustules and often then open and have a classic honey-colored crust, surrounding erythema, or both. This patient’s rash of flesh-colored papules that have been present for 2 weeks is not consistent with impetigo. Athletes with impetigo should not return to contact sports until they have undergone 72 hours of antibiotic treatment (e.g., with mupirocin) with complete resolution of drainage and no new lesions.

E) INCORRECT:

The National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) has set forth specific return-to-competition guidelines for collegiate athletes with molluscum contagiosum. According to these guidelines, solitary or localized clustered lesions on the trunk or upper thigh must be completely covered for the athlete to compete. This athlete’s lesions are on his torso, are few in number, and can be covered with a gas permeable membrane and tape, in addition to clothing, before engagement in contact sports so that transmission is minimized. For more extensive infections, the lesions should be treated with curettage and then covered before return to play.

A solitary pustule with surrounding erythema is visible in the center of the image. In many cases of folliculitis, a single hair can be seen in the middle of the lesion.

E) INCORRECT:

The National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) has set forth specific return-to-competition guidelines for collegiate athletes with molluscum contagiosum. According to these guidelines, solitary or localized clustered lesions on the trunk or upper thigh must be completely covered for the athlete to compete. This athlete’s lesions are on his torso, are few in number, and can be covered with a gas permeable membrane and tape, in addition to clothing, before engagement in contact sports so that transmission is minimized. For more extensive infections, the lesions should be treated with curettage and then covered before return to play.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman presents with multiple small, flesh-colored papules in the anogenital region and the mons pubis. She reports that the lesions have been stable in size for two weeks and are mildly pruritic but not painful. She is sexually active with multiple partners and denies dysuria or discharge. She has a history of mild eczema and noticed similar lesions on her trunk over the past two months, some of which resolved spontaneously. On examination, the papules measure 2–5 mm in diameter, with some appearing slightly inflamed at the periphery (see image).
Laboratory tests, including HIV testing, are pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum is a viral infection caused by a poxvirus, presenting with small, dome-shaped, flesh-colored papules with central umbilication. The lesions are typically 2–5 mm in diameter and can appear in the anogenital region, especially in sexually active adults. The stable size, mild pruritus, and presence of similar lesions on the trunk align with the nature of this condition. Genital lesions in sexually active patients should prompt screening for other sexually-transmitted infections including HIV.

Key learning point: Molluscum contagiosum presents as firm, smooth, skin-colored papules with a central dimple, commonly found in the anogenital area, and can occasionally become inflamed and itchy.

B) INCORRECT:

Verruca vulgaris, commonly caused by HPV types 2 and 4, presents as hyperkeratotic, rough-surfaced papules, typically on the hands or face. The smooth, dome-shaped, flesh-colored papules in the anogenital region, along with similar lesions on the trunk, do not align with the presentation of verruca vulgaris.

C) INCORRECT:

Condyloma acuminatum, caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), typically presents as verrucous, cauliflower-like lesions rather than uniformly small, dome-shaped, flesh-colored papules. These lesions usually do not regress spontaneously and are not typically associated with mild pruritus. The described lesion morphology and clinical course are inconsistent with condyloma acuminatum.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex infection presents with painful vesicles that evolve into ulcerative lesions, often accompanied by dysuria and tender lymphadenopathy. The stable, flesh-colored papules described, along with the absence of pain and rapid lesion evolution, do not match the typical presentation of herpes simplex.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-week history of multiple skin lesions. The lesions are neither painful nor itchy. She has no history of serious illness. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Vital signs are normal. On skin examination, you observe nontender, pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication, measuring 9–17 mm in diameter, located on the face, neck, trunk, axillae, antecubital fossae, lower abdomen, and proximal thighs. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassure the patient that the lesions will resolve and recommend follow-up.
Perform an HIV screening test and recommend cryotherapy.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical salicylic acid is a desquamating agent used as second-line therapy for localized molluscum contagiosum; it is not an appropriate therapy for this patient with disseminated molluscum contagiosum. Salicylic acid is also commonly used to treat acne vulgaris and verruca vulgaris. Acne vulgaris typically manifests with tender, inflammatory papules and pustules on the face. Verruca vulgaris typically manifests with cauliflower-like papules and/or plaques on acral surfaces.

B) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum is typically a self-limited disease. However, this patient has widespread involvement, which is consistent with disseminated molluscum contagiosum and unlikely to resolve on its own. She, therefore, requires further management.

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic itraconazole therapy can be used to treat invasive fungal infections (e.g., blastomycosis, histoplasmosis, aspergillosis) but is not used to treat molluscum contagiosum, which is caused by a poxvirus. Disseminated fungal infections can manifest with a widespread papular eruption, but they typically have more variable findings (e.g., nodules, ulcers, pustules). In addition, disseminated fungal infections commonly also cause extracutaneous symptoms, such as fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and weight loss, which this patient does not have.

D) INCORRECT:

Curettage is commonly used to treat localized molluscum contagiosum. Curettage of select lesions (e.g., the most bothersome lesions) may be a reasonable initial approach for this patient with disseminated molluscum contagiosum, but it may also result in multiple, large wounds that increase the risk of developing other infections. In addition, treatment alone without evaluation of possible immune system dysfunction is inappropriate in patients with extensive lesions.

E) CORRECT:

Because disseminated molluscum contagiosum in an adult raises concern for underlying immunocompromise, an HIV screening test is indicated for patients presenting with this condition. In the case of HIV infection, antiretroviral therapy should be initiated in conjunction with the treatment of skin lesions. Treatment for molluscum contagiosum includes cryotherapy, curettage, and topical cantharidin. Cidofovir may be considered in immunocompromised individuals with severe or refractory lesions. A reasonable initial approach for this patient is to treat the largest and/or most bothersome lesions with cryotherapy, which is a destructive method that can also stimulate an enhanced immune response to viral antigens.

Key learning point: Disseminated molluscum contagiosum in adults suggests possible immunodeficiency, so HIV screening and lesion-directed therapy such as cryotherapy are indicated.
Image Description:

Photograph of the eyelid of an adult

Multiple skin-colored papules with central umbilication are visible.

These features are characteristic of molluscum contagiosum.
questions.hint: This patient's widespread eruption of nontender, pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication is consistent with a diagnosis of disseminated molluscum contagiosum.

questions.text: You are seeing a previously healthy 2-year-old girl who is brought to your clinic by her mother because of multiple skin lesions on her abdomen. She attends daycare three times per week, and her mother reports that another child at the daycare had similar lesions this past week. Her immunizations are up-to-date. A photograph of the lesions is provided. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chickenpox (varicella) typically manifests during childhood with a rash that is characterized by the simultaneous manifestation of macules, papules, vesicles, and crusts. The rash starts on the trunk, spreading to the face, scalp, and extremities and causing severe pruritus and fever.

B) CORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum typically affects children < 5 years of age. The lesions are nontender, skin-colored, pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication. They are usually 2–5 mm in diameter and commonly occur on the trunk, face, and genitalia. Because spontaneous remission often occurs within a year, treatment is usually not required.

Molluscum contagiosum also occurs in adults, particularly in those with immunosuppression (e.g., HIV, chemotherapy, extensive corticosteroid therapy).

Key learning point: Molluscum contagiosum presents as multiple small, skin-colored, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication, most commonly affecting young children and often resolving spontaneously without treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Insect bites (e.g., mosquito or flea) typically cause pruritic lesions and physical examination most often reveals erythematous papules at the site of the bite.

D) INCORRECT:

Folliculitis is characterized by erythema, tender papules, and/or pustules at the site of hair follicles. However, the patient's papules are nontender and there is no association with hair follicles, making the diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Common warts (verruca vulgaris) manifest as rough, scaly papules or plaques that may sometimes have a cauliflower-like appearance and are typically located on the hands, feet, and knees.
questions.hint: This patient's skin lesions are typically caused by poxviruses.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a 6-week history of asymptomatic skin lesions that have been slowly increasing in number. The parent reports that the child attends daycare and asks about keeping the child at home. Physical examination findings are shown. The child appears well with no fever or systemic symptoms. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Advise expectant management with infection control measures

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bacterial culture is not indicated for typical molluscum contagiosum lesions that are nontender and show no signs of secondary bacterial infection. The characteristic umbilicated appearance distinguishes molluscum contagiosum from bacterial skin infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Urgent dermatology referral is not necessary for typical molluscum contagiosum in healthy children. Referral is indicated for severe or refractory disease, particularly in immunocompromised patients, or if treatment is specifically desired for cosmetic or other reasons.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids are not indicated for typical molluscum contagiosum lesions in patients who are otherwise asymptomatic. While corticosteroids may be used for associated molluscum dermatitis (eczematous reaction around the lesions), this patient has no signs of perilesional inflammation or pruritus that warrants anti-inflammatory treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Typical topical antivirals are not effective for molluscum contagiosum. While cidofovir may be considered for severe or refractory disease in immunocompromised patients, it is not indicated for routine treatment in otherwise healthy children.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Expectant management is appropriate for immunocompetent children with molluscum contagiosum. The condition typically resolves spontaneously within 1 year. Caregivers should be educated about infection control measures, and isolation from daycare is not necessary because the risk of transmission is low.
